title: 112_s3438
content:
The Offshore Petroleum Expansion Now Act of 2012, also known as the Proposed Oil and Gas Leasing Program: 2012-2017, requires the implementation of the Proposed Final Outer Continental Shelf Oil and Gas Leasing Program. The Act defines terms like OCS Planning Area and Secretary. The Offshore Petroleum Expansion Now Act of 2012, known as the Proposed Oil and Gas Leasing Program: 2012-2017, mandates the implementation of the program according to specified schedules and laws. The Secretary is required to conduct oil and gas lease sales in OCS Planning Areas as outlined in the Act. Lease Sale No. in various OCS Planning Areas:

Lease sale number 250 will be conducted for lease tracts in the OCS Planning Area and Mid-Atlantic OCS Planning Area by the Secretary, as specified in the table under subsection (b) and in accordance with the Act. SEC. 4. SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA EXISTING INFRASTRUCTURE LEASE SALE. The Secretary must offer leases for sale in the Santa Maria and Santa Barbara or Ventura Basins of the Southern California OCS Planning Area by December 31, 2013. Leases must require development and production from existing offshore infrastructure or onshore-based drilling unless the Governor of California requests an area-wide sale within 1 year of the next scheduled lease sale. SEC. 5. REVISED MAP OF THE MID-ATLANTIC PLANNING AREA. The Secretary will revise the map of the Mid-Atlantic planning area to align the leasable area with the tidal shoreline length of Delaware, Maryland, North Carolina, and Virginia. This revision will be based on information from NOAA's document "The Coastline of the United States." SEC. 6. NATIONAL DEFENSE. The Act does not affect the Secretary of Defense's authority to designate national defense areas on the Outer Continental Shelf. No oil or gas activities under this Act should conflict with military operations as determined by the Department of Defense and the Department of the Interior. The Secretary of Defense and the Secretary of the Interior agreed on terms for exploration, development, or production activities before the lease issuance date. SEC. 7. ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT STATEMENT REQUIREMENT. The Secretary must prepare a multisale environmental impact statement for lease sales required by this Act. The statement does not need to consider nonleasing alternatives or analyze their environmental effects. The Secretary must identify a preferred leasing action and no more than one alternative proposal. The Secretary must prepare a multisale environmental impact statement for lease sales required by this Act, identifying a preferred leasing action and one alternative proposal for analysis of environmental effects and mitigation measures. SEC. 8. EASTERN GULF OF MEXICO PROTECTIONS. This Act does not impact restrictions on oil and gas leasing under the Gulf of Mexico Energy Security Act of 2006.

SEC. 9. AREA-WIDE LEASE SALES. Lease sales under this Act, except for specific exceptions, shall be area-wide lease sales.

SEC. 10. COASTAL STATE REVENUE SHARING FOR OUTER CONTINENTAL SHELF ENERGY SOURCES. For fiscal years 2012 through 2022, 37.5 percent of revenues from outer Continental Shelf areas not scheduled for lease sale will be deposited in a special account for coastal States and political subdivisions. For fiscal year 2023 and onwards, 37.5 percent of revenues from outer Continental Shelf areas will be deposited in a special account for coastal States and political subdivisions, allocated based on a formula established by the Secretary. The Secretary will allocate revenues from outer Continental Shelf areas to coastal States and political subdivisions based on a formula that considers the distances between the coastline and leased tracts. 25 percent of the allocable share of each coastal State will be paid to its political subdivisions according to specific allocation criteria. The Secretary will distribute revenues from renewable and nonrenewable energy sources on the outer Continental Shelf to coastal States and political subdivisions. These revenues are in addition to those provided under the Gulf of Mexico Energy Security Act of 2006. Limitations on the amount of distributed qualified Outer Continental Shelf revenues are repealed. The Gulf of Mexico Energy Security Act of 2006 is amended by removing subsection (f), with the amendment taking effect 10 years after enactment.
